tossups.question: Characters in this novel pretend to impersonate J. P. Morgan and military officers before one asks, “What’s a left flank?” A man in this novel calls another man “a furious blaze of liquid life-energy” and asks when “the delicate balance between social order and thirsty aspiration” will topple skyscrapers. In this novel, men watch a movie preview in which a society girl runs with her Communist boyfriend on the beach; that same couple later makes the protagonist take them to (*) Charlie’s Kitchen Shack. This novel’s protagonist scares his sister Vera with a rat after killing it with a skillet. James Baldwin named an essay collection of “Notes” after this novel, in which an earring is found in a furnace, leading Boris Max to defend a man who kills his girlfriend Bessie. For 10 points, name this novel in which Mary Dalton is smothered by Bigger Thomas, written by Richard Wright.

Early people in this group were transported on Tumbeiro by people like Martim Afonso de Sousa. These people formed religious brotherhoods dedicated to Our Lady of the Rosary. Joaquim Nabuco was a leading activist supporting these people. These people invented a fighting dance which may have its roots in imitating zebra fighting. Some of these people practicing Islam rose up in the Male Revolt. Former members of this group were led in one place by King Zumbi. The role of them in the (*) Casa Grande system is discussed in a work by Gilberto Freyre. Previous members of this group became known as Maroons and created interior settlements like Palmares called quilombos. These people benefited from the Law of Sexagenarians and from the Law of the Free Womb. For 10 points, name this class of people who received freedom in the Golden Law.
tossups.answer: slaves in Brazil [prompt on “Brazilians,” “Africans,” “Black people,” or “Indians” with “in what class”]

tossups.question: One of this author’s narrators remembers the years of her childhood distinctly, but can’t tell the years apart while raising her own children. After seeing an article about another artist, that woman concludes “Fame must be striven for, then apologized for” and realizes that she withdrew affection from her daughter after a leukemia scare. In one of this author’s stories, Laird’s older sister lets a horse escape slaughter and is dismissed with the phrase, “She’s only a girl.” This author of (*) Hateship, Friendship, Courtship, Loveship, Marriage wrote about Janet, who visits a planetarium while awaiting the outcome of her father’s operation. This author’s Miss Marsalles hosts a piano recital at which a girl with Down syndrome plays the title song. For 10 points, “Dance of the Happy Shades” and “The Moons of Jupiter" are short stories by what Canadian author?

Jin-Quan Yu’s group developed a series of MPAA derivatives used as these compounds in C-H activation reactions. Salicylaldehyde and an amine are condensed to form salen, which is often used as one of these compounds. The cube of the distance of closest approach of one of these compounds is found in the rate law for a reaction in which two of these things are exchanged, called the Eigen-Wilkins mechanism. These compounds decrease the B Racah parameter in the (*) nephelauxetic effect. The number of contiguous atoms that one of these compounds uses to bond is designated eta and is called the hapticity. Those that bind to two centers are called bridging, and those that make more than one bond with one center are called polydendate. For 10 points, name these compounds that bind to a central transition metal atom in a coordination complex.

The only comprehensive architectural history of these institutions is a 1972 book by Wolfgang Braunfels. The only surviving systematic architectural drawing of the Middle Ages depicts an idealized one of these institutions and is dedicated to its leader Gozbert. Art historian Erwin Panofsky explored the influence of scholastic theology on the leader of another of these institutions, who commissioned for it the first truly Gothic building. (*) Churches belonging to these institutions were simplified during the Cistercian reforms. A church attached to one of these institutions is the traditional burial site of the kings of France. St. Gall in Switzerland and St. Denis in Paris are both Benedictine examples of, for 10 points, what building complexes that house communities of monks?

Jean-Baptiste Fiard claimed that the Jacobins, who attacked the power of the Catholic Church during the French Revolution, were practitioners of this religion. Dyrendal, Lewis, and Petersen have categorized variants of this faith as reactive, rationalist, and esoteric. A prominent branch of this tradition promotes (*) nonconformism and individualism, and includes nine central statements promoting “vengeance instead of turning the other cheek” and denouncing “concern for psychic vampires.” One organization in this tradition has five degrees of hierarchy, including Magister and Magus. That organization founded by Anton LaVey uses the head of Baphomet as a symbol. For 10 points, name this religious movement that generally treats its namesake figure allegorically rather than as the literal devil.
tossups.answer: Satanism [or the Church of Satan; or LaVeyan Satanism]

tossups.question: Description acceptable. Advocates of this political cause pressured the Senate to override a presidential veto of the Webb-Kenyon Act. Walt Whitman’s terrible early novel Franklin Evans was circulated by a group supporting this cause called the Washingtonian Society. The concept of “pressure politics” was pioneered by a group supporting it whose leaders included William “Pussyfoot” Johnson. State laws favoring this cause were often modeled on the reforms (*) Neal Dow enacted while mayor of Portland, Maine. Supporters of this cause went to “hatchetations” inspired by the activist Carrie Nation. The ASL and WCTU supported this cause, which was enacted nationally by the Volstead Act. For 10 points, identify this cause whose supporters favored the passage of the 18th Amendment.
tossups.answer: prohibition [also accept temperance; accept any answers that describe banning the sale or consumption of alcohol]

tossups.question: Kyoo Lee attempted to modernise this author by “Reading [this philosopher] Otherwise.” This philosopher was compared to Daffy Duck by Steven Nadler in a biography framed by an analysis of a famous portrait of this thinker. Bernard Williams argued that this philosopher failed at his primary ambition in a book on his Project of Pure Enquiry. This philosopher’s time at the Jesuit academy of La Fleche influenced the structure of his primary work, in which this thinker analogizes his method to the task of sifting rotten (*) apples from a basket by emptying it and replacing only the good apples, which can be seen as examples of what this thinker calls “clear and distinct perceptions.” The first section of that work by this philosopher closes by imagining a malicious demon. For 10 points, name this author of Meditations on First Philosophy.

This man promoted a project to build a Branch Davidian church in memory of the church members who died in the 1993 Waco Siege. In 1998, this man released his first film, “America Destroyed by Design.” In Richard Linklater’s film Waking Life, an animated version of this man yells through a megaphone while his face turns purple, blue, and scarlet. A Rolling Stone article claimed this man made (*) Rush Limbaugh and Glenn Beck sound like “tea-sipping NPR hosts on Zoloft” and called him “the most paranoid man in America.” This man’s website advertises products like “Survival Shield X-2” and “Super Male Vitality.” In 2013, this man proclaimed on CNN that “1776 will commence again” if the government attempts to disarm Americans. For 10 points, name this conservative conspiracy theorist known for creating the website “InfoWars.”

The absence of the HOX11 gene prevents this organ from developing. A disease whose two other main symptoms are rheumatoid arthritis and neutropenia has enlargement of this organ as a third symptom; that is Felty’s triad. That enlargement of this organ can be found by percussing the lowest intercostal space and seeing if the note changes from resonant to dull. That is (*) Castell’s sign. Loss of this organ increases susceptibility to pneumococcus, meningococcus, and other encapsulated bacteria. The cords of Billroth are found in this organ and it is often enlarged and fragile in mononucleosis. Sickle cell anemia can cause sequestration of this organ, which is present on the left side of the abdomen. For ten points, name this organ whose white pulp synthesizes antibodies and whose red pulp filters red blood cells.

This person presided over the first public meeting of the Society for the Extinction of the Slave Trade at Exeter Hall. This person had the governess Louise Lehzen exiled in a power struggle. This person defeated the Earl of Powis to become Chancellor of the University of Cambridge. Lord Palmerston claimed that only himself, a mad German professor, and this person understood the Schleswig-Holstein problem. This non-head of state was advised by Baron Stockmar. As chief organizer of the Great (*) Exhibition, this person commissioned Charles Fox and Joseph Paxton to create a building known as the “Crystal Palace.” This person faced mistrust because he was an ancestor of the German House of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha. This person’s wife wore black for the rest of her life due to grief over his death. For 10 points, name this Prince consort of Queen Victoria.
tossups.answer: Prince Albert of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha

tossups.question: This man instructed a jockey to throw down his cap at the spot where his horse stumbled; when he later ordered that spot be excavated, he discovered a pot of gold that he used to repay his master. This man tricked his rival Heinin Vardd so that he was unable to say anything other than “Blerwm, Blerwm” in front of the king. This man advised his mistress to disguise her maid as herself in order to avoid the advances of (*) Prince Rhun. Although he is not Finn MacCool, this man gained knowledge after burning his thumb on a potion of knowledge, after which he transformed himself into a grain of wheat to evade the vengeful sorceress Ceridwen. For 10 points, name this Welsh “chief of the bards” who names a Frank Lloyd Wright estate in Wisconsin.
tossups.answer: Taliesin [or Shining Brow; or Gwion Bach ap Gwreang]

tossups.question: One artist from this country created a painting in which huge crowds gather on a mountain to stare at a giant dead chicken. Another artist from here painted a Greek column, a statue of Buddha, and many guns in a pile behind Christ with an axe destroying his cross. That artist also painted a skeleton made partially of books giving birth to another skeleton. “The March of Humanity” was created in this country. One artist from here came to the U. S. to paint (*) Detroit Industry; that man’s most famous work contrasts a statue of Zeus and a bayoneted army with a headless statue and a red-flag-carrying army. That mural featuring crossed ellipses around a hand holding an orb, which was destroyed due to its depiction of Lenin, is Man at the Crossroads. For 10 points, name this country home to artists like David Siqueiros, Jose Orozco, and Diego Rivera.

This man names an effect in which shear stress on a granular material causes it to dilate. This man names a generalization of the Leibniz integral rule to three dimensions. An operator named for this scientist sets the velocity equal to a fluctuation term plus an average value. Relative roughness, the Darcy-Weisbach friction factor, and a quantity named for this (*) scientist all appear on a Moody diagram. One quantity named for this scientist, whose namesake averaging is used to simplify the Navier-Stokes equation, is equal to velocity times linear dimension over kinematic viscosity and gives the ratio of inertial forces to viscous forces. For 10 points, name this British scientist who names a quantity that’s high for turbulent flow and low for laminar flow.

A poet from this country wrote that “the joy of writing” is “the power of preserving” and “the revenge of the mortal hand.” This country’s Skamander group, founded in 1918, produced poems focused on modern life. One of this country’s “Three Bards” opened his best-known poem by comparing this country’s neighbor to “good health,” which “I never knew till now / How precious, till I lost thee.” The lines “Every beginning / is only a sequel, after all” appear in (*) “Love at First Sight,” a poem by a female poet from this European country who won the 1996 Nobel. This country, whose national epic is titled Pan Tadeusz, was the birthplace of a poet who wrote about the response of this country’s intellectuals to Soviet rule in The Captive Heart. For 10 points, name this home of Adam Mickiewicz, Wisława Szymborska, and Czeslaw Milosz.

One piece named after this thing begins with English horn and clarinet rapidly ascending triplets at tempo marked “anime et tres rythme”; Camille Chevillard conducted the premiere of that piece by Debussy along with Nuages (noo-azh). A tenor trombone solo depicts a drunkard in the final movement of one work named after this type of event. Britten’s Variations on a Theme of Frank Bridge was first premiered during one of these events. It’s not a dance, but (*) one type of these events names a collection of three piano pieces, the first of which begins with alternating G major seventh and D major seventh chords. Hans Richter conducted the first premiere of the Ring Cycle during one type of these events that takes place annually in Bayreuth. For 10 points, name these celebratory events, of which the “Roman” variant was depicted by Respighi.
tossups.answer: festivals [or Roman festivals or music festivals; accept fete before “trombone solo”; prompt on “celebrations”]

tossups.question: CIA Station Chief James Angleton manipulated an election determining this position by skimming money   from the Exchange Stabilization Fund and exchanging money at the Hassler Hotel. This was the highest position involved in the “Bribesville” scandal and investigated by the “Clean Hands” judges. A holder of it passed workers’ protections after a series of strikes during the “Hot Autumn.” One holder of this position reconciled with Berlinguer of the Communist Party in the (*) “Historic Compromise.” The dead body of a holder of this position was discovered in the trunk of a Renault 4 car after he was kidnapped for 55 days by the Red Brigades. Another holder of it often had prostitutes in attendance at his wild “bunga-bunga” parties. For 10 points, name this position held by Aldo Moro and Silvio Berlusconi.
tossups.answer: Prime Minister of Italy [or Premier of Italy; President of the Council of Ministers of Italy; Presidente del Consiglio dei ministri della Repubblica Italiana; do NOT accept or prompt on “President of Italy”]

tossups.question: They’re not planets, but red-shifted absorption lines in the spectrum of beta pictoris were posited to be formed by these objects. JFCs and HTCs are subclasses of these objects, many of which are designated by a number, followed by a P, then a slash and a name. The Rosetta probe launched the Philae lander onto one of these objects. Remnants of these objects are responsible for the Orionids, (*) Perseids, and Leonids, the last of which is caused by Tempel-Tuttle. Short period ones originate in the Kuiper Belt, and long period ones originate in the Oort cloud. For 10 points, name these astronomical objects that contain an icy nucleus surrounded by a coma and tail, that include Hale-Bopp and one named for Edmund Halley.

This thinker argued that language, religion, and division of labor held human communities together. This man’s normative theory envisioned a future in which people would “live for others.” His quest for discovering “invariant laws of the natural and social world” was pursued through observation, experimentation, and comparison. The distinction between social structure and social change originated from the distinction he drew between (*) social statics and social dynamics. He put forth the idea of a hierarchical complexity of sciences, beginning with the simplest, astronomy, and ending with social science. This thinker believed that society passed through theological, metaphysical, and scientific stages, which he outlined in The Course in Positive Philosophy. For 10 points, name this French philosopher who both founded and coined the term “sociology.”
tossups.answer: Auguste Comte [or Isidore Marie Auguste François Xavier Comte]

tossups.question: In one essay, this author argued that Victor Hugo wanted to create a complete fictional world and use it to change the real world. In exchange for cigarettes, a literary boy writes pornography for other students who also have sex with the prostitute Golden Toes and the dog Skimpy in a novel by this author of “The Temptation of the Impossible.” A chauffeur elopes with Don Fermin in a novel which asked “At what precise moment” his country had (*) “fucked itself up.” This author wrote about members of “the Circle” stealing answers to a chemistry test in a novel where Jaguar kills the Slave while they are students at a military academy. In one of his novels, Santiago and Ambrosio meet in a dog pound and talk about a minister’s shady dealings in the title bar. For 10 points, name this Peruvian author of The Time of the Hero and Conversation in the Cathedral.

bonuses.leadin: These objects are a spinor field and its complex conjugate that both are solutions of their namesake equation. For 10 points each:
answer: scattering amplitude [or S-matrix elements; prompt on “amplitudes” or “probability amplitudes”]
parts: Name these mathematical constructs developed by Roger Penrose, which exist in a four-dimensional space that can map to Minkowski space

Ed Witten embedded one of these theories into twistor space. These theories, five of which were also united by Witten to form M-theory, predict that particles are actually vibrating one-dimensional objects.

Witten developed twistor string theory to find these quantities, the square of the magnitude of which gives the differential cross section. The LSZ reduction formula is used to calculate them from correlation functions.

bonuses.leadin: This work opens with the Alexander Herzen quote “It would be extremely interesting to write the history of laughter.” For 10 points each:
answer: Rabelais and His World [or Tvorčestvo Fransua Rable i narodnaja kul'tura srednevekov'ja i Renessansa]

Russia [or Rossiyskaya Federatsiya or Rossiyskaya Sovetskaya Federativnaya Sotsialisticheskaya Respublika or the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic or SFSR; prompt on “USSR” or “Soviet Union”]
parts: Name this Mikhail Bakhtin work that discusses his concepts of the carnivalesque and the grotesque. It focuses on the series Gargantua and Pantagruel.
In The Dialogic Imagination, Bakhtin outlined the concepts of heteroglossia, dialogism, and this other concept, referring to the way that temporal and spatial relationships interact in literature.
Bakhtin is from this country. He wrote about one of its authors in Problems of Dostoyevsky’s Art.

bonuses.leadin: This man claims that “To he who avenges a father, nothing is impossible” - even though getting revenge for his father involves killing his lover’s dad Don Gormas. For 10 points each:
answer: the Cid [or el Cid or le Cid or Rodrigue or Rodrigo]
parts: Name this Moor-fighting Castilian hero from a medieval Spanish lay. This exiled knight duels Don Sanche over his love Chimene.
This French dramatist adapted a Spanish epic to create the play Le Cid. He also wrote about the title character converting Pauline and Felix to Christianity in Polyeucte.

In The Lay of the Cid, the Cid marries his daughters to these princes, then shows them up when he kills a lion which they are scared of. They get revenge by tying his daughters to trees, so he beats them up.

bonuses.leadin: Sir John Norreys carried out the English Fury at this city, capturing and plundering it with Calvinist assistance. For 10 points each:
answer: Fernando Alvarez de Toledo y Pimental [or Duke of Alba; Duke of Alva; prompt on “Iron Duke”]
Spanish Armada [or Grande y Felicisima Armada; the Invincible Armada; Armada Invencible]
parts: Name this city that couldn’t catch a break during the Dutch Revolt, as it was the victim of the first “Spanish Fury” during that conflict as well. One general claimed that “no nail was left in the wall” after a sack of this city.
This Spanish general conducted the sack of Mechelen. This general created the bloody “Council of Troubles,” which killed the Count of Egmont, due to his anger of Iconoclastic Fury.
The Duke of Alba served under King Philip II, who ordered this failed attempt to invade England and depose Queen Elizabeth.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about athletes taking a knee during the national anthem.
answer: Oakland Athletics [or Oakland A’s; accept either underlined part]
parts: The controversy over anthem protests started when this former 49ers quarterback kneeled before a preseason game in 2016 to protest against police brutality and racial inequality.

This NASCAR team owner came out against the protests when he threatened to fire any driver that kneeled during the anthem. This person won the Daytona 500 seven times during his career and is nicknamed “The King.”
The first MLB player to kneel during the national anthem was Bruce Maxwell, a catcher for this team. This team is prominently featured in the movie Moneyball.

bonuses.leadin: Remember the Titans. Specifically, for this bonus. For 10 points each:
parts: This Titaness was the personification of justice and law. This mother of the Fates built the Oracle of Delphi, where she told Deucalion and Pyrrha how to create a new human race.
In another story, both Themis and the Fates arose from the waters of this Titan, a god of the sea encircling the world. His consort is Tethys.

This hero crossed Oceanus in a golden bowl given to him by the Titan Helios. He defeated Oceanus' sons the Cercopes and carried them on a pole upside down, but let them go when he realized they could see his butt.

bonuses.leadin: One beneficiary of this operation was reviled with the lines: “‘Once the rocket comes up who cares where it comes down? That’s not my department,’ said [this person].” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this operation, code-named Overcast, in which United States intelligence brought Nazi rocket scientists like Wernher von Braun to the U. S. to keep their experience away from the Soviet Union.

Wernher von Braun helped develop these “vengeance weapons,” liquid-propellant rocket-fueled ballistic missiles used by the Germans during WWII, which were the first artificial objects to travel into outer space.

This scientist, brought over in Operation Paperclip, used his expertise in submerging people in freezing water at Dachau to design the Gemini and Apollo spacesuits. He is often known as the “father of space medicine.”

bonuses.leadin: For ten points each, name some things about female Rococo artists, who were apparently really into floppy hats.
parts: Adélaïde Labille-Guiard painted one of these; it included two of her female students hovering over an easel. Elisabeth Vigee-Lebrun painted one of these in which the subject holds a palette and wears a feathered hat.
Rosalba Carriera was a Rococo portraitist who often worked in this medium, which was popular in this time due to its soft visual nature. This medium’s binder was often made of gum arabic.
Carriera made a pastel portrait depicting this Roman goddess with her breasts bared. Vigee-Lebrun included more clothing in her painting of her daughter Julie allegorized as this goddess.

bonuses.leadin: In a short story by this writer, Ana is thrown into panic by the sight of a blind man chewing gum. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author of the short stories “Love” and “The Smallest Woman in the World.” The hot-dog-eating typist Macabea gets hit by a Mercedes after seeing a fortune teller in this author’s novel The Hour of the Star.
Lispector hailed from this country, also home to an author who wrote about a woman’s affair with the ghost of Vadinho in Dona Flor and Her Two Husbands, Jorge Amado.
Lispector’s “The Fifth Story” presents five increasingly bizarre stories about killing these insects, one of which the narrator of her The Passion According to G. H. eats.

bonuses.leadin: This politician installed two cannons inside the office of his newspaper, the True American, to defend it from a pro-slavery mob. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this owner of White Hall plantation, a former slaveholder who become a voraciously anti-slavery Republican. He is said to have defeated the entire Turner family in a duel using only his trademark Bowie knife.
Along with his more famous cousin, Henry Clay, Cassius represented this US state.

In the 1860s, Cassius Clay took a break from knifing dudes to serve as ambassador to this country, which he lobbied to support Lincoln during the Civil War. John Quincy Adams was the first American ambassador to it.

bonuses.leadin: Gaspar Sanz wrote three pedagogical volumes on this instrument that introduced the “Italian alphabet” system for each chord. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this typically six-stringed instrument played by Andres Segovia. Joaquin Rodrigo wrote his Concierto de Aranjuez for this instrument.
While this Spanish composer never composed guitar works, many transcriptions of piano works such as Leyenda and Tango in D remain as an important part of modern classical guitar repertoire.
This composer rearranged many of his string quintets into Guitar Quintets at the request of Marquis de Benavente. Of those that survived, his Guitar Quintet No. 4 “Fandango” remains popular today.

bonuses.leadin: When asked if these people could call God “the God of our fathers,” Maimonides wrote that while he might descend from Jacob, these people derive from God himself. For 10 points each:
answer: converts [or ger or gerim or giyoret; prompt on “stranger” or “foreigner” or “resident”]
beth din [accept “house of judgment” before it is read]
parts: Name these former gentiles toward whom Maimonides had an unusually positive and accepting view.
Some people call this woman the first convert to Judaism due to her famous pledge that “your people shall be my people and your God shall be my God.”
People wishing to convert were traditionally questioned by one of these religious courts. An orthodox one of these “houses of judgment” requires three scholars versed in Halakhic law.

bonuses.leadin: This minister ousted rivals like Zhang Jiuling and Pei Yaoqing. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this longest ruling Chancellor during the reign of Emperor Xuanzong. This incredibly corrupt and awful minister appointed non-Han Chinese like An Lushan to important border posts to protect his power.

Emperor Xuanzong was infatuated with this one of the “Four Beauties of China.” This person’s cousin Yang Guozhong was as bad a Chancellor as Li Linfu, and Xuanzong was forced to kill her during the An Lushan Revolt.

Emperor Xuanzong was a ruler during this dynasty, typically regarded as the first post-Han Golden Age in China. This dynasty succeeded the Sui dynasty, and poets such as Li Po and Du Fu were active during it.

bonuses.leadin: A fake brochure made as part of this play claims that pants falling down are an “allusion to the Fall of Man” and that “sardines are even more plagued than their human cousins by the problem of doubles and lookalikes.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this play, which shows a rehearsal and two disastrous showings of the sex farce Nothing On, once entirely from behind. Chaos erupts due to love triangles among the directors and cast.
Noises Off! was written by this playwright who fictionalized the relationship between Werner Heisenberg and Niels Bohr in Copenhagen and also wrote the novels Headlong and Spies.
This other British comic playwright riffed on Hamlet in Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are Dead and wrote about mathematical prodigy Thomasina Coverly in Arcadia.

bonuses.leadin: The brilliant Spartan general Brasidas died while defending this city against the Athenian firebrand Cleon, who also perished in the battle. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this city in Chalcidice on the River Strymon. The historian Thucydides was tried and exiled for his failure to protect this city from the Spartans, and the battle of this city led to the signing of the Peace of Nicias.
The Battle of Amphipolis occurred during this lengthy war between Sparta and Athens, chronicled by the aforementioned historian Thucydides and ending in the Battle of Aegospotami.

Brasidas had earlier thwarted an Athenian attempt to capture this city. A decree named for this city promulgated by Pericles forbade Athenian trade with this city, which helped spark the Peloponnesian War.

bonuses.leadin: This anthropologist introduced “group-grid” theory to describe social networks. For 10 points each:
answer: magic [or witchcraft or sorcery or other equivalents]
kosher laws [or kashrut; do not accept or prompt on “halal”]
parts: Name this British anthropologist who defined dirt as “matter out of place” and discussed how ideas of dirt and pollution enforce taboos in Purity and Danger.
Douglas was a student of E. E. Evans-Pritchard, who discussed this concept as practiced by the Azande. James Frazier divided it into contagious and sympathetic varieties.
Douglas has since rejected her previous theory that these religious restrictions enforced “symbolic boundaries” rather than protecting dietary health or serving as tests of one’s commitment to God.

bonuses.leadin: This ecologist explained exaggerated male characteristics with runaway sexual selection. For ten points each:
answer: sex ratio [don’t take equivalents, this is a reified term]
parts: Name this ecologist who developed ANOVA while analyzing genetic data, as well as a fundamental theorem of natural selection.

That fundamental theorem says that the rate of increase of this quantity is equal to genetic variance. Multiplying this quantity by genotype frequency in a given generation gives the frequency in the next generation.
Fisher also gave an explanation for why this quantity is usually close to one for a population, which is his namesake principal. This quantity is the ratio of males to females in a population.

bonuses.leadin: This man’s film Blow Job is a 35-minute uninterrupted shot of DeVeren Bookwalter’s face as he receives oral sex offscreen. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this man who collaborated with Paul Morrissey on films like Lonesome Cowboys and Chelsea Girl. Valerie Solanas tried to kill this man after he misplaced a copy of her screenplay, Up Your Ass.

One of Warhol’s best-known films is continuous slow-motion shot of this New York City landmark at night. This Art Deco skyscraper was the tallest building in the world until the construction of the World Trade Center.

Jonas Mekas, who shot the footage for Warhol’s Empire, championed the career of this other experimental filmmaker. This director of the “cosmological epic” Dog Star Man used graphic footage of a real autopsy in his film The Act of Seeing with One’s Own Eyes.

bonuses.leadin: This author wrote that “Fragments are the only forms I trust” in his story “See the Moon?” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this postmodern author of Unspeakable Practices, Unnatural Acts and Come Back, Dr. Caligari, known for his collage-like style. The title giant object lands over New York City in his short story “The Balloon.”

A fragmentary “Newsreel” style was used by this modernist author of Three Soldiers, who depicted characters like the journalist Jimmy Herf, the actress Ellen Thatcher, and the politician George Baldwin in Manhattan Transfer.

Dos Passos’ “Newsreels,” featuring headlines and other snippets, were from this series consisting of The 42nd Parallel, 1919, and The Big Money. It follows the interwoven lives of Mac, Janey Williams, and Eleanor Stoddard.

bonuses.leadin: Name some things about chemically modeling cell membranes, for 10 points each:
answer: the Gibbs–Donnan effect [or the Donnan law or Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium]
parts: ORP measures the “potential” to undergo this type of reaction, the tendency of a chemical species to acquire electrons. This process is paired with oxidation in a redox reaction.

This equation is used to determine the reversal potential across a cell membrane which is not in thermodynamic equilibrium due to ion pumps. It calculates membrane potential as RT/F times the natural log of (the positive ions outside the cell + negative ions inside the cell, over the negative ions outside the cell + positive ions inside the cell).

This effect occurs when charged particles near a semi-permeable membrane fail to distribute evenly across each side. It is often caused by the presence of another substance to which the membrane is not permeable.
